summary: The European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA) has its own Vulnerability Database, called the European Union Vulnerability Database (EUVD). It’s datasource is The Vulnerability Lookup project, a system that correlates various sources and streamlines Coordinated Vulnerability Disclosure (CVD). It uses the Global CVE Allocation System (link) as a source. This system is created with funding by the EU and is maintained by Computer Incident Response Center Luxembourg (CIRCL), with a nice dashboard here.
title: European Union Vulnerability Database

Uncle Bob, in his presentations, likes to say that the number of developers in the world doubles every 5 years. Recently The Primeagen in one of his shorts he echos that statement. They both do not give any source for this information, so can it be validated?
The Netherlands has an agency called Centraal Bureau voor de Statistiek (CBS) which collects all kinds of statistics about the country. It turns out that they also have statistics on the type of field people work in.
title: Developer Growth

Rust has allows for a pattern called Type-Driven Design. In the below example a SubscriberName is created. It has a single String value. In simple code this might be represented as let subscriber_name = "Arjen".to_string();. By making the type you can wrap the validation logic into the creation of the type. This means that wherever you get a paramter of type SubscriberName you know it is valid.
